2o) la mention que le candidat est de nationalité guinéenne de naissance et qu'il jouit de ses droits civils et de ses droits politiques conformément à l'article L 157 de la présente loi ;

3o) la dénomination du parti politique qui accorde l'investiture ;

4o) la signature du candidat ;

5o) la couleur choisie pour l'impression des bulletins de vote et éventuellement le symbole ou signe qui doit y figurer.

 

Article L 160 La déclaration de candidature doit être accompagnée des pièces suivantes :

- un certificat de nationalité ;

- un extrait d'acte de naissance ;

- un bulletin no 3 du Casier judiciaire datant de moins de trois mois ;

- un certificat médical de visite et de contre-visite datant de moins de trois mois ;

- le récépissé de dépôt du cautionnement prévu à l'article L 181.

 

Article L 161 Pour s'assurer de la validité des candidatures déposées et du consentement des candidats, la Cour Suprême fait procéder à toute vérification qu'elle juge utile.

 

Article L 162 Conformément à l'article 26, alinéa 3 de la Loi Fondamentale, la Cour Suprême arrête et publie la liste des candidats trente neuf (39) jours avant le premier tour de scrutin. Cette publication est faite par affichage au greffe de la Cour Suprême. Les électeurs sont convoqués par décret trente huit (38) jours avant le scrutin.

 

Article L 163 Le droit de réclamation contre toute candidature est ouvert à tout parti politique légalement constitué.

Les réclamations doivent parvenir au greffe de la Cour Suprême avant l'expiration du jour suivant celui de l'affichage de la liste des candidats.

La Cour Suprême statue sans délai.

 

Article L 164 Si la Cour Suprême constate le décès ou l'empêchement définitif de tout candidat à la Présidence de la République figurant sur la liste prévue à l'article L 162, elle décide, s'il y a lieu, de rouvrir les délais pendant lesquels des candidatures nouvelles peuvent être déposées. Dans ce cas, une nouvelle date du scrutin est fixée dans les conditions prévues à l'alinéa 3 de l'article 25 de la Loi Fondamentale.

 

Article L 165 Dans le cas où, à l'issue du premier tour, aucun candidat n'a obtenu la majorité absolue, il est procédé à un deuxième tour de scrutin dans les délais et conditions prévus à l'article 25 alinéa 2 et l'article 29 alinéa 2 de la Loi Fondamentale.

Les retraits éventuels de candidature à ce deuxième tour sont portés à la connaissance de la Cour Suprême par les candidats 24 heures au plus tard, après la proclamation du résultat du premier tour.

La Cour Suprême arrête alors et publie par affichage la liste des deux seuls candidats admis à se présenter au second tour.

 

Article L 166 La convocation des électeurs pour le deuxième tour est faite par décret sept (7) jours au moins avant le scrutin.

 

Chapitre 2 : De La Campagne Electorale

 

Article L 167 La campagne électorale est ouverte trente (30) jours avant le scrutin et close la veille de celui-ci à zéro heure.

En cas de deuxième tour, la campagne électorale est ouverte le lendemain de la proclamation des résultats du premier tour et close la veille du deuxième tour à zéro heure.

Elle se déroule dans les deux cas conformément aux dispositions du chapitre 6, titre 1 de la présente loi.

 

Chapitre 3 : Des Opérations Electorales

 

Article L 168 Le scrutin pour l'élection du Président de la République a lieu conformément à l'article 25 alinéa 1 de la Loi Fondamentale, quarante cins (45) jours au plus et trente (30) jours au moins avant la date de l'expiration du mandat du Président de la République en fonction.

Toutefois, dans les cas de vacance prévus à l'article 34 de la Loi Fondamentale, le scrutin pour l'élection du Président de la République a lieu, sauf cas de force majeure constaté par la Cour Suprême, trente cinq (35) jours au moins et cinquante (50) jours au plus après l'ouverture de la vacance.

 

Article L 169 Le corps électoral est convoqué par décret du Président de la République trente huit (38) jours avant le scrutin, conformément aux dispositions de l'article L 65 de la présente loi.

Le dépouillement, le recensement des votes, la publication des résultats des bureaux de vote, la totalisation globale des résultats et la publication de cette totalisation ont lieu conformément aux dispositions du titre 1, chapitre 7, section 3 de la présente loi.

 

Chapitre 4 : Du Recensement General Des Votes Et De La Proclamation Des Resultats

 

Article L 170 Le recensement général des votes et la transmission du procès-verbal de ce recensement à la Cour Suprême par le Ministre chargé de l'Intérieur s'effectuent conformément aux dispositions de l'article L 151.

 

Article L 171 Le Ministre chargé de l'Intérieur rend publique la totalisation globale des résultats dans le délai maximum de quarante huit heures.

 

Article L 172 Si aucune contestation relative à la régularité des opérations électorales n'a été déposée par l'un des candidats au greffe de la Cour Suprême dans les huit (8) jours qui suivent le jour où la première totalisation a été rendue publique, la Cour Suprême proclame élu le Président de la République.

Est élu le candidat qui a obtenu la majorité absolue des suffrages au premier tour, la majorité simple au second tour.

En cas de contestation, les résultats sont proclamés dans les conditions définies à l'article L 176 de la présente loi.

 

Chapitre 5 : Du Contentieux

 

Article L 173 Dans les conditions et délais fixés par l'article 30 alinéa 1 de la Loi Fondamentale, tout candidat au scrutin peut contester la régularité des opérations électorales sous la forme d'une requête adressée au Premier Président de la Cour Suprême.

 

Article L 174 La requête est déposée au greffe de la Cour Suprême.

Il en est donné acte par le Greffier en chef.

Sous peine d'irrecevabilité, la requête doit préciser les faits et moyens allégués et respecter les délais de dépôt.

 

Article L 175 La requête est communiquée par le Greffier en chef de la Cour Suprême aux autres candidats intéressés qui disposent d'un délai maximum de 24 heures pour déposer un mémoire en réponse. Il est donné récépissé du dépôt du mémoire par le Greffier en chef.

 

Article L 176 La Cour Suprême statue dans les trois (3) jours qui suivent la saisine. Son arrêt emporte proclamation définitive ou annulation de l'élection.

En cas d'annulation, de nouvelles élections sont organisées dans les soixante (60) jours.

 

Titre 7 : Des Dispositions Financieres

 

Article L 177 Les actes de procédures, les décisions et registres relatifs aux élections sont dispensés de timbre, de l'enregistrement et des frais de justice.

Les cartes d'électeurs, les bulletins de vote, les circulaires sont dispensés d'affranchissement en période électorale.

 

Article L 178 Sont à la charge de l'Etat, les dépenses résultant de la fourniture des cartes d'électeurs ainsi que celles de l'organisation des élections. Les dépenses engagées par les partis politiques durant la campagne électorale sont à leur charge.

 

Article L 179 Les barèmes de la rémunération pour prestations inhérentes à la préparation matérielle et au déroulement du scrutin à la charge des pouvoirs publics, sont fixés par arrêté conjoint du Ministre chargé de l'Intérieur et de celui des Finances.

 

Article L 180 Les campagnes électorales sont financées aux moyens :

- des ressources des partis politiques ;

- des subventions éventuelles de l'Etat accordées équitablement ;

- éventuellement, des revenus des candidats.

Les modalités d'application des dispositions du présent article sont fixées par voie réglementaire.

 

Article L 181 Sur proposition d'une Commission des Finances composée :

- du Ministre chargé de l'Intérieur, Président ;

- du représentant du Ministre des Finances, Rapporteur ;

- des représentants de chacun des partis légalement constitués, et engagés dans l'élection, membres ;

- le Ministre chargé de l'Intérieur fixe par arrêté au plus tard soixante (60) jours avant le scrutin :

- le montant du cautionnement à verser au trésor public contre récépissé, quarante (40) jours au moins et cinquante neuf (59) jours au plus avant celui du scrutin, par les candidats ou les mandataires des partis politiques prenant part à une élection législative ou présidentielle ;

- et le plafond autorisé du montant global des dépenses pouvant être engagées par un candidat ou un parti politique prenant part à une élection législative ou présidentielle.

 

Article L 182 Le cautionnement représente la contrepartie de la prise en charge par l'Etat des frais d'impression des bulletins de vote, professions de foi et affiches de propagande dans les conditions fixées par la partie réglementaire du présent Code électoral.

 

Article L 183 Le cautionnement est remboursé aux candidats ou aux mandataires des partis politiques dans les quinze jours qui suivent la proclamation définitive des résultats.

Ont droit au remboursement intégral du cautionnement :

- tout candidat élu ou ayant recueilli au moins 5 % des suffrages exprimés au scrutin majoritaire uninominal à un tour des législatives ;

- toute liste ayant obtenu un siège ou recueilli au moins 5 % des suffrages exprimés au scrutin de liste nationale à la proportionnelle ;

- tout candidat à l'élection présidentielle ayant recueilli au moins 5 % des suffrages exprimés.

 

Article L 184 Il est interdit à tout parti politique ou à tout candidat prenant part à une élection législative ou présidentielle d'engager pour la campagne électorale des dépenses excédant le plafond autorisé par la commission indiquée à l'article L 181.

 

Article L 185 Tout parti politique ou candidat engagé dans une élection doit constituer pour ses dépenses électorales, un fonds dénommé "Fonds électoral" alimenté conformément aux dispositions de l'article L 180.

 

Article L 186 Les partis politiques, les candidats prenant part aux élections législatives ou présidentielles sont tenus d'établir un compte de campagne.

Le compte de campagne reçoit le "Fonds électoral".

Le compte de campagne retrace l'origine du "Fonds électoral" et l'ensemble des dépenses effectuées pendant les opérations électorales.

La personne responsable des dépenses électorales ne doit puiser que dans ce "Fonds électoral" pour défrayer les dépenses électorales.

 

Article L 187 Dans les trente (30) jours qui suivent la proclamation définitive des résultats, les partis politiques ou les candidats ayant pris part au scrutin déposent auprès de la Chambre des comptes de la Cour Suprême leur compte de campagne accompagné des pièces justificatives des ressources et des dépenses effectuées.

Ces comptes sont certifiés à la Chambre des Comptes de la Cour Suprême par des comptables agréés.

La Chambre des Comptes de la Cour Suprême rend publics les comptes de campagne afin de recueillir dans un délai de quinze (15) jours les observations des citoyens et des partis politiques sur lesdits comptes.

 

Article L 188 Après vérification des pièces justificatives des comptes, la Cour Suprême rend son arrêt. S'il est constaté un dépassement des dépenses de campagne par rapport au plafond autorisé, la Chambre des Comptes de la Cour Suprême adresse dans les quinze (15) jours qui suivent le dépôt des comptes, un rapport au Procureur de la République qui doit engager des poursuites judiciaires contre les contrevenants.

 

titre 8 : Des Pénalités

 

Article L 189 Toute personne qui se fait inscrire sous un faux nom ou une fausse qualité, ou qui, en

se faisant inscrire a dissimulé une incapacité prévue par la loi, ou qui réclame et obtient une inscription sur plus d'une liste, sera punie d'un emprisonnement d'un à six mois et d'une amende de 100 000 à 250 000 FG ou de l'une de ces deux peines seulement.

 

Article L 190 Toute personne qui, à l'aide de déclaration frauduleuse ou de faux certificats se sera fait inscrire ou aura tenté de se faire inscrire sur une liste électorale, ou qui, à l'aide des moyens frauduleux aura fait inscrire ou rayer indûment un citoyen, sera punie des peines prévues à l'article L 189 de la présente loi.

 

Article L 191 Toute personne qui, déchue du droit de voter, par suite d'une condamnation judiciaire, ou par suite d'une faillite non suivie de réhabilitation, a voté, soit en vertu d'une inscription sur les listes antérieures à sa déchéance, soit en vertu d'une inscription postérieure, mais opérée sans sa participation, sera punie des peines prévues à l'article L 189 de la présente loi.

 

Article L 192 Quiconque aura voté, soit en vertu d'une inscription obtenue frauduleusement, soit en prenant faussement les nom, prénoms, et qualités d'un électeur inscrit, sera puni d'un emprisonnement de six mois à un an et d'une amende de 250 000 à 500 000 FG ou de l'une de ces deux peines seulement.

 

Article L 193 Sera puni des peines prévues à l'article L 192 le citoyen qui a profité d'une inscription multiple pour voter plus d'une fois. La même peine est appliquée à quiconque a empêché par inobservation volontaire de la loi, l'inscription sur une liste électorale d'un citoyen remplissant les conditions fixées par le présent Code.

 

Article L 194 Toute infraction aux dispositions des articles L 48 alinéa 3, L 54 et L 55 sera punie d'un emprisonnement de six mois à un an et d'une amende de 100 000 à 200 000 FG ou de l'une de ces deux peines seulement.

 

Article L 195 Quiconque étant chargé dans un scrutin de recevoir, compter ou dépouiller les bulletins contenant les suffrages des citoyens, a soustrait, ajouté ou altéré des bulletins, ou a lu volontairement un nom autre que celui inscrit, sera puni d'un emprisonnement de six mois à un an, d'une amende de 250 000 à 500 000 FG et de l'interdiction du droit de voter et d'être éligible pendant cinq ans au moins et dix ans au plus.

Toutes autres personnes coupables des mêmes faits énoncés dans l'alinéa premier seront punies d'un emprisonnement de six mois au moins et un an au plus, d'une amende de 100 000 à 250 000 FG ou de l'une de ces deux peines seulement.

 

Article L 196 A l'exception des membres des forces publiques légalement requis, quiconque est entré dans un bureau de vote avec une arme apparente sera passible d'une amende de 250 000 à 500 000 FG.

La peine sera d'un emprisonnement de quinze jours à trois (3) mois et d'une amende de 50 000 à 100 000 FG si l'arme était cachée.

 

Article L 197 Sera puni d'une emprisonnement de quinze jours et d'une amende de 25 000 F, quiconque aura introduit ou tenté d'introduire dans un bureau de vote des boissons alcoolisées.

Quiconque aura introduit ou tenté d'introduire des stupéfiants dans un bureau de vote, sera poursuivi et puni conformément à la loi.

 

Article L 198 Quiconque à l'aide de fausses nouvelles, propos calomnieux ou autres manoeuvres frauduleuses aura détourné des suffrages ou déterminé un ou plusieurs électeurs à s'abstenir de voter, sera puni d'un emprisonnement d'un mois à un an et d'une amende de 100 000 à 500 000 FG ou de l'une de ces deux peines seulement.

 

Article L 199 Quiconque trouble les opérations d'un bureau de vote, porte atteinte à l'exercice du droit électoral ou à la liberté de vote, ou empêche un candidat ou son représentant d'assister aux opérations de vote, est puni d'un emprisonnement de six mois à deux ans et d'une amende de 250 000 à 1 000 000 FG ou de l'une de ces deux peines seulement.

Si le coupable est porteur d'arme, il encourt une peine d'emprisonnement de un à cinq ans et une amende de 500 000 à 1 500 000 ou l'une de ces deux peines seulement.

Lorsque les infractions prévues aux alinéas 1 et 2 ci-dessus sont commises par suite d'un plan concerté pour être exécuté, le coupable sera puni d'un emprisonnement de cinq à dix ans, et de l'interdiction de droit de voter et d'être éligible pendant cinq ans au moins et dix ans au plus et d'une amende de 250 000 à 1 500 000 FG.

 

Article L 200 Quiconque commet un outrage ou exerce des violences envers un ou plusieurs membres d'un bureau de vote, ou qui, par voies de fait ou menaces, aura retardé ou empêché les opérations électorales, sera puni d'un emprisonnement de six mois à deux ans et d'une amende de 100 000 à 500 000 FG sans préjudice des poursuites judiciaires pouvant être engagées par la victime.

 

Article L 201 L'enlèvement irrégulier de l'urne contenant les suffrages émis et non encore dépouillés, ou des procès-verbaux ou de tout document constatant les résultats du scrutin, sera puni d'un emprisonnement d'un à cinq ans et d'une amende de 250 000 à 1 500 000 FG ou de l'une de ces deux peines seulement.

Si cet enlèvement a été effectué par un groupe de personnes et avec violence, la peine sera de cinq à dix ans d'emprisonnement et l'amende de 1 500 000 à 3 000 000 FG.

 

Article L 202 La violation de l'urne soit par un membre de bureau, soit par un agent de l'autorité préposé à la garde des bulletins non encore dépouillés, sera punie d'un emprisonnement d'un à cinq ans et d'une amende de 1 500 000 à 3 000 000 FG.

 

Article L 203 Quiconque par des dons ou libéralités en espèce ou en nature, par des promesses de libéralités, de faveurs, d'emplois publics ou privés ou d'autres avantages, aura influencé ou tenté d'influencer le vote d'un ou plusieurs électeurs ou d'un collège électoral à s'abstenir de voter, sera puni d'un emprisonnement de trois mois à deux ans et d'une amende de 50 000 à 500 000 FG ou de l'une de ces deux peines seulement.

Ces peines seront assorties de la déchéance civique pendant une durée de cinq ans.

Seront punis des mêmes peines, ceux qui auront agréé ou sollicité les mêmes dons, libéralités ou promesses.

 

Article L 204 Tout candidat qui, de mauvaise foi, aura souscrit une déclaration inexacte sur son éligibilité ou sur sa présence sur une liste, sera puni d'un emprisonnement d'un mois à un an et d'une amende de 50 000 à 250 000 FG.

 

Article L 205 Quiconque, soit dans une commission de contrôle de listes électorales, soit dans une commission administrative, soit dans un bureau de vote, ou en dehors de ceux-ci, avant, pendant ou après un scrutin, aura, par inobservation volontaire des lois et règlements en vigueur ou par toute manoeuvre ou actes frauduleux, porté atteinte ou tenté de porter atteinte à la sincérité du vote, empêché ou tenté d'empêcher les opérations du scrutin, violé ou tenté de violer le secret du vote ou aura changé ou tenté de changer le résultat, sera puni d'un emprisonnement de un mois à un an et d'une amende de 150 000 à 600 000 FG.

Le coupable pourra en outre être privé de ses droits civiques pendant deux ans au moins et cinq ans au plus.

S'il est fonctionnaire de l'ordre administratif ou judiciaire, agent ou préposé de l'autorité publique, la peine sera portée au double.

 

Article L 206 Ceux qui par menace contre un électeur, soit en lui faisant craindre de perdre son emploi ou d'exposer à un dommage sa personne, sa famille ou ses biens, l'auront déterminé à voter ou auront influencé ou tenté d'influencer son vote seront punis d'un emprisonnement de trois mois à un an et d'une amende de 50 000 à 500 000 FG, ou de l'une de ces deux peines seulement.

Lorsque ces menaces sont accompagnées de violence ou de voies de fait, les peines sont celles prévues par l'article L 200 de la présente loi et par le Code Pénal.

 

Article L 207 Quiconque enfreint les dispositions visées à l'article L 42 sera puni d'un emprisonnement d'un mois à un an et de l'interdiction du droit de vote et d'être éligible pendant un an au moins et cinq ans au plus.

 

Article L 208 Toute personne qui en violation des articles L 56 et L 57, utiliserait ou laisserait utiliser à son profit les attributs, biens et moyens de l'Etat, d'un organisme public, d'une association, d'une organisation non gouvernementale, sera punie des peines d'emprisonnement de six mois à deux ans et d'une amende de 250 000 à 2 500 000 FG.

 

Article L 209 Tout imprimeur qui enfreindra aux dispositions de l'article L 53 alinéa 4 sera puni d'une amende de 75 000 FG par modèle d'affiches ou de bulletins.

Les affiches ou bulletins incriminés sont immédiatement retirés de la circulation par acte du Ministre chargé de l'Intérieur ou du Préfet.

 

Article L 210 Quiconque enfreint aux dispositions relatives à l'établissement des comptes de campagne prévu à l'article L 186 sera puni d'un emprisonnement d'un à cinq ans et d'une amende de 1 500 000 à 3 000 000 FG, ou de l'une des deux peines seulement.

 

Article L 211 Aucune poursuite contre un candidat, en vertu des articles L 202 et 210 ne peut être exercée avant la proclamation du scrutin.

 

Article L 212 Les pénalités prévues au présent titre sont applicables sans préjudices des autres sanctions prévues par les lois et règlements en vigueur.

Les complices des infractions visées au présent titre sont punissables.

 

Article L 213 Toute condamnation prononcée dans le cadre de la présente loi ne pourra, en aucun cas, avoir pour effet, l'annulation d'une élection régulièrement validée par les instances compétentes.

 

Titre 9 : Dispositions Finales

 

Article L 214

La présente loi organique qui abroge toutes dispositions contraires sera publiée au Journal Officiel de la République de Guinée et exécutée comme Loi de l'Etat.

Conakry, le 23 décembre 1991

Général Lansana Conté

 

 

English version

 

The Transitional National Recovery, after some debate, adopted;
The President of the Republic promulgated the Act set out below


Part 1: The Provisions of Common to all Elections and Consultations

Chapter 1: General Provisions

Article L 1: Suffrage is universal, direct, equal and secret.

Article L 2: The Minister of Interior has the authority, which is organizing the elections. The Courts shall ensure the regularity of the elections and resolve electoral disputes under the conditions defined by this Act.
In accordance with the Fundamental Law, the Supreme Court shall ensure the regularity of presidential and legislative elections.
The Ministry of the Interior is required to inform the Supreme Court of various acts and transactions relating to these elections.
The Supreme Court may, at any time, prescribe any measures it deems appropriate to the regularity and the proper conduct of elections.


Chapter 2: The Requirements to Be Elector

Article L 3: Are voters, all Guinean at least 18 years old on election day, enjoying their civil and political rights, notwithstanding the provisions of Article 443 of the Civil Code, and not being in any condition of incapacity provided by the law in force.

Article L 4: The conditions for the electorate of naturalized aliens are laid down by Article 89, paragraph 2 of the Civil Code.
Women who acquired Guinean nationality through marriage under the conditions laid down by Article 49 of the Civil Code are voters, in accordance with the provisions referred to in Article 53 of the Civil Code.
Also voters, foreigners with the right to vote under reciprocal agreements.

Article L 5: Nobody can vote:
-If he is not registered on the electoral roll of the electoral district where is his home within the meaning of Article 244 of the Civil Code;
-He has lived for at least six months home in the said home, subject to the provisions of Article 10 below;
-If he has not fulfilled its civic duties;
-If he has not a national identity card and a certificate of residence or one of the documents listed in Article 21 of this Act.


Chapter 3: The Electoral Lists

Section 1: Conditions For Inclusion On The Electoral Lists

Article L 6: The registration on the electoral roll is compulsory for every citizen fulfilling the conditions required by law.

Article L 7: Nobody can be registered on more than one list of electors or to be registered more than once on the same list.

Article L 8: Should not be included in the electoral roll except in the case of rehabilitation:
1)Individuals convicted of the crime;
2)Those sentenced to a term of imprisonment without probation or a sentence of imprisonment for a term exceeding one month, with or without a fine, for any of the following offences:
-Theft;
-Fraud;
-Breach of trust;
-Misappropriation and embezzlement committed by a public official;
-Corruption and influence peddling;
3) Those convicted of a crime of counterfeiting, and in general, for one of the offences punishable exceeding five years;
4) Those sentenced to more than three months imprisonment without probation, or a sentence of imprisonment for a term not exceeding six months sentence for a crime other than those mentioned in the second paragraph above;
5) Those who are in a state of absentia;
6) non rehabilitated bankrupts whose bankruptcy has been declared either by Guinean courts, or by a foreign judgement enforceable in the Republic of Guinea;
7)Internees and incapacitated adults;
8)Individuals to whom the courts have forbidden the right to vote.

Article L 9: There is a list of electors for each commune and for each Community of Rural Development (CRD). A copy of this list is submitted to the Sub-Prefecture for the file of sub-prefects, in the prefecture for the file of prefecture, governorate, for the city of Conakry and the Ministry of the Interior responsible for the general file. It is also compiled a list of voters for each diplomatic mission in the Republic of Guinea.
These lists form the consular file kept by the Ministry of Foreign Affairs. Copies of these lists are filed by the Ministry of Foreign Affairs to the Ministry of the Interior responsible for the general file.

Article L 10: The voter list of municipalities include:
1) All voters who are domiciled in the municipality or resident for at least six months at the time of registration;
2) Those who are subject to a compulsory residence as an officer or agent of the State, local government and public institutions, or as an agent of corporations and private enterprises.

Article L 11: In Community Rural of Development, the electoral list includes all voters who have their main residence there.

Article L 12: Are also registered on the electoral rolls in the Municipalities and Community of Rural Development, who, while not fulfilling the terms of age and residency during the establishment of the electoral list, attain that age before the final closure of lists.

Article L 13: Notwithstanding the provisions of Article 5, paragraph 1 Guinean citizens established or in service abroad and registered in the Chancery of Guineans Embassies or Consulates, are registered on the electoral roll of the Embassy or Consulate.

Article L 14: The electoral list must include the name, affiliation, occupation, date and place of birth of each voter and the neighborhood or district of residence.

Article L15: The production of a certificate of residence and one of the requirements of Article 21 is required of any individual who seeks its inclusion on a voter list.

Article L 16: Every citizen referred to in articles 5 and 13 can claim the inclusion of a non-registered voter or cancellation of a voter improperly registered. That same opportunity will be provided to the Mayor, the President of the Community of Rural Development.
Applications from third parties cannot have the purpose other than registration or individual radiation. They must specify the identity of each person whose registration or cancellation is claimed. Any voter whose registration is challenged must be informed within three business days so that he could submit its comments to the Administrative Commission. The notification, which must be made free of charge, will contain an indication of the reason for the request for cancellation.
In the event of cancellation, he may challenge the decision of the Administrative Commission, which is responsible for him to provide the reasons for his challenge to the President of the Court or Judge of the Peace in the period from 1 to 15 December. This period is reduced to eight days in the event of exceptional revision of electoral lists. Any omitted voter can also submit his comments to the Administrative Commission and file, if necessary, his complain to the presiding judge or the Justice of the Peace. 

Article L 17: The Court of First Instance or the Justice of the Peace of each Prefecture sit by ordinance on the case of a dispute. The ordinance is not liable to appeal.


Section 2: The Establishment and Revision of Electoral Lists

Article L 18: The voters lists of municipalities are drawn up by one or more administrative commissions consist of:

-A representative of the government appointed by the prefect or by the Governor of the city of Conakry and acting as President;
-The City Mayor or his representative;
-A representative of each candidate or list of candidates;
The voter list of Communities of Rural Development are drawn up by one or more commissions consisting of administrative:
-A delegate of the administration appointed by the sub-prefect and acting as President;
-The Chairman of the Community of Rural Development or his representative;
-A representative of each candidate or party list of candidates.
The administrative commissions for the revision of voter list must associate in their work, the heads of the district or representatives thereof.


Article L 19: The period of revision of electoral rolls is scheduled to be held from October 1 to December 31 each year. The Mayor or the Chairman of the Community of Rural Development Council carries out the posting of the notice of opening of the period revision of voter registration by October 1.
Applications for registration or cancellation are expressed with the competent departments of Municipalities and Communities of Rural Development during the period stipulated in the first paragraph of this article. Fifteen days prior to the end of registration, the Mayor and the Chairman of the Community of Rural Development shall conduct the posting of a notice of closure of operations of revision.

 
Article L 20: In case of an exceptional revision of electoral rolls, the dates for opening and closing of the revision period shall be determined by decision of the Minister of the Interior before the convening of the electorate.

Article L 21:The electoral lists are permanent.
They are subject to annual revision.
They are drawn from census records and supplemented in accordance with the provisions of Articles 18 L, 19 L 20 L. The preparation and revision of electoral rolls are made upon presentation of one of the following documents.
-Identity card;
-Passport;
-Military record;
-Booklet of civil or military pension;
-Student card of the current school year;
-Consular card;
-A certificate from the district chief and counter-signed by two prominent citizens of the District for rural people.

The administrative commission shall provide each voter a receipt bearing the registration number on the electoral roll.
The elections are conducted on the basis of the revised list in the last trimester of the year preceding that of elections.

Article L 22: As part of the annual revision of electoral rolls, it is

prepared from December 1st of every year with a table of correction consisting of:
-Newly registered voters or ex officio by the Administrative Commission or at the request of voters;
-Voters removed or ex officio by the Administrative commission or at the request of voters.

 

Article L 23: This table of correction must bear all the indications of identity that must appear on the electoral roll and the reasons for listing or delisting.
The corrigendum, once adopted, should be signed by the president and all members of the Administrative Commission and tabled at the City Hall or at the headquarters of the Community of Rural Development accompanied by a certificate of deposit.

Article L 24: The Mayor of the municipality or the President of the Community of Rural Development must:
1) give notice to the people of this filing through poster affixed to the usual places and making known that the claims are received for a period of 15 days;
2) send within two days to the regulatory authority, a copy of the table of correction and a copy of the minutes of the filing.

Article L 25: The table of registration and cancellation established by the Administrative Commission is posted at the usual place of official publications on November 30. Minutes of the work deposited to mayor’s office or the Chairman of the Community of Rural Development can be accessed by whoso wishes or copied at his expense with out displacing the said document.

Article L 26: The original work submitted to the City Council or the Community of Rural Development can be transmitted to any claimant interested in receiving one or copying at its own expense, but without moving those documents.

Article L 27: Complaints are recorded in a register opened for this purpose at the City Hall or at the headquarters of the Community of Rural Development. They are worn in the chronological order of their submission and must include the full name, affiliation, date and place of birth and residence of each claimant and the statement of the grounds on which they are based. The claims are made in writing. He must be given a receipt.

Article L 28: The claims are reviewed by the court or justice of the peace, which has ten days to decide. The decision must be brought to the attention of people interested in the three days of the judgement.

Article L 29: The decisions of the court can be communicated to all applicants wishing to obtain this information, the secretariat of the Town Hall or at the headquarters of the Community of Rural Development, but without displacing the said documents.

Article L 30: The Administrative Commission brings to the tables which were published on November 30 all changes resulting from the decisions of the Tribunal of the First Instance or justice of the peace. Moreover, it removed the names of voters whose deaths have occurred since the publication of the correction table and the names of those who have been deprived of the right to vote by a final judgement.
It will table these amendments, which must be signed by the president and all members and immediately forwarded to the Mayor or to the headquarters of the Community of Rural Development and to the regulatory authority.

Article L 31: Not later than January 8, the changes on the table of correction are carried to the electoral roll, which becomes the electoral roll for the current year.
The lists are finalized on January 8 of each year.
The new voters' list will be tabled at the Secretariat of the Town Hall or at the headquarters of the Community of Rural Development. It can be transmitted to any claimant who may consult or take copies at his own expense.
A copy shall be sent:
-In the sub-prefect for the file of the Sub-prefecture;
-To the Prefect for the file of the Prefecture;
-Minister of the Interior responsible for the general file.

Section 3: Registration or Cancellation Outside the Periods for Review

Article L 32: The following may be included or removed on completion of the electoral list at least 24 hours before the ballot:
-Functionaries of services or public institutions, private or public companies, officials of public or private companies that have been subject to transfer or who have retired as well as members of their families living with them at the time of the transfer or retirement upon presentation of their decisions to transfer or retirement and the certificate of cancellation issued by the authority of the former residence;
-Guineans who have reached the age of majority for election, on production of documentary of evidence;
-Guineans registered abroad when they return on an interim basis in one of the electoral districts, on presentation of their consular card;
-Voters already registered on the electoral roll when they change their  place of residence on presentation of the certificate of cancellation issued by the authority of the former residence;
-People whose registration or cancellation has been ordered by the courts in accordance with the law.

 

Chapter 4: Control Of The Registration an Electoral Lists

Article L 33: The Minister of the Interior shall maintain the general registration of voters for inspection of voter registration. A decree lays down the conditions for the organisation and functioning of this file, files Sub-prefecture and prefecture.

Article L 34: When it is found that on general file a voter is recorded by mistake on more than one list, its inclusion is maintained on the list of its most recent application. His cancellation other lists occurs automatically. When the same voter is registered by mistake more than once on the same list, he must not remain but on a single registration.
Every cancellation is communicated by the Minister of Interior to Prefect and the Sub-prefect to update their files.
The cancellation is made upon production of documentary evidence.

Chapter 5: Voters’ Cards

Article L 35: The government is responsible for the printing and preparation of voters' cards at the expense of the state.

Article L 36: The model cards and the modalities for establishing and expiry date are determined by a decision of the Minister of Interior.

Article L 37: The Governor for the city of Conakry and prefects for their Prefecture, named by decision members of the commission of the distribution of voters’ cards forty-five days before the election.

Article L 38: A voting card mentioning the electoral list and indicating the polling station where the voter will vote shall be issued to each voter. This distribution starts 30 days before the polling day and ends on the eve of the polling day. The handing over of the cards is to be held against a receipt as mentioned in article L 21 by the commissions provided for in article L 35 in places of distribution to be determined by an act of the Mayor or the President of the Community of Rural Development.
The electoral cart is strictly individual and cannot be subject to transfer, assignment or negotiation.

Article L 39: Registration cards, which have not be taken by the voters until the eve of the vote, are delivered against receipt to clustered commissions of distribution designated by the Governor for the city of Conakry and prefects for prefectures.
They remain kept for the interested voters throughout the duration of the election. However, they can be returned to their owner as justification for their identity and presentation of the receipt.
For a receipt of a card, which has not been found, the President of the Commission regrouped immediately authorizes for the establishment of a new card after checking on the electoral roll. At the close of polling, the Commission establishes consolidated Minutes signed by all members.
Those cards not withdrawn at the close of polling, returned under seal stamped and initialled by the Commission consolidated to the Governor for the city of Conakry and the Prefect for the Prefectures. These cards will be kept for the next Review Board, which will decide on the validity of the registration of their respective owners.

Article 40 L: The color of voters' cards should vary from one election to another. The renewal of registration cards may be decided at any time by the Minister of the Interior.


Chapter 6: The Electoral Campaign

Article L 41: Election campaigns are declared open:
1) for the municipal and rural elections fifteen days before the polling day;
2) for the legislative elections, twenty days before polling day;
3) for the presidential elections thirty days before polling day.
They all end on the eve of the day before the vote at zero hour. The dates of opening and closing of the campaigns are set by decree of the President of the Republic.

Article L 42: Nobody can by any means and in whatever form campaign outside the period stipulated in the previous article.

Article L 43: The following are the only authorized to organize meetings for campaign:
-Candidates or representatives of the lists of candidates in local elections or the election of Communities of Rural Development;
-Political parties legally constituted.

Article L 44: The demonstrations, gatherings for elections are conducted in accordance with the provisions of the law on public meetings and demonstrations.

Article L 45: The electoral meeting, which aims is the choice or hearing of candidates in the elections, is open only to candidates, their agents and members of their party.

Article L 46: The demonstrations, gatherings for election cannot be held on site or public roads without prior declaration made to the Mayor or the President of the Community of Rural Development at least 24 hours in advance. They are prohibited between 23 pm and 7 am. The declaration must be made in written form and during the legal hours of opening of administrative services.
The statement mentions the names and positions of officers of the meeting. Receipt will be given. If no designation by the signatories of the statement, the officers are elected by the meeting at the beginning of it.

Article L 47: Each meeting should have a bureau consisting of at least three members.
The officers and the signatories of the statement are responsible for breaches of the requirements of this article and article L 46 and are liable to penalties prescribed by law for such offences. The Bureau is responsible for maintaining law and order, to give the meeting a characteristics mentioned by the statement, to prohibit any speech contrary to public order and morals or containing incitement to an act constituting a crime or misdemeanor. And in general to prevent any breaches of the laws.

Article L 48: An official of the administrative or judicial order may be delegated by the administrative authorities to attend the meeting.
He chooses his place. It reports on the progress of the meeting to the competent authority.
If there is a disturbance or assault, the president of the Bureau, lest fall within the scope of

Article L 196 of this Act, stops the meeting.

Article L 49: During the election period, in the municipalities or in Community of Rural Development, the Mayor or the President of the Rural Community Development designates by an administrative act:
-Places exclusively to receive posters, laws, acts of the public authorities on the ballot;
-Special places reserved for professions of faith, circulars and posters.
In each of these locations, a surface area is allocated to each individual candidate or list of candidates. Any display on the election, even poster stamped, is prohibited outside these sites, or on sites for other candidates. The locations are allocated in the order of arrival of requests.

Article L 50: Requests should be addressed by candidates or representatives of political responsible parties to the Minister of the Interior, the prefect or sub-prefect, as appropriate, no later than eight (8) days before the election. They are recorded and transmitted to the mayor or the President of the Community of Rural Development. 

Article L 51: Each individual candidate or political party with a candidate or list of candidates, can be printed and sent to voters during the election campaign, a circular of propaganda sheet including a double-sided format of 21 X 27; This circular is subject to the formality of legal deposit.


Article L 52: The campaign through displays is governed by the provisions of Articles L 49 and L 50.

Article L 53: A candidate or a political party may not use a title, color, a logo, a symbol or sign already chosen by another candidate or another political party.
If two or more candidates or lists of competitors adopt the same color or even the same emblem or symbol or sign, the Minister of the Interior rules within eight (8) days by allocating to each candidate or list his colour, emblem, symbol or sign in order of seniority.
It informs concerned parties.

 
It prohibits the choice of emblem with a combination of the three national colors: red, yellow, green.

Article L 54: It is prohibited under the penalties provided for in Article 196 L [194] of this Act, to distribute on the polling day, newsletters, bulletins or other documents of propaganda.

Article 55 L: It is an offence for any public official to distribute during his hours of service, newsletters, bulletins or other documents of propaganda under the penalties provided for in Article L 196  [194].

Article L 56: Are prohibited and may be punishable, upon action of the Public Prosecutor, penalties applicable to influence peddling:
- Donations and gifts in cash or in kind as well as pledges, gifts or administrative favors made to an individual, a commune or community of any citizens for propaganda purposes in order to influence or attempt to influence the voting. 
-Using for the same purpose goods and means of an institution or a government agency and the state in general;
-Using for the same purpose any process to commercial advertising.

Article L 57: Associations and apolitical Non-Governmental Organizations, and especially those with supports and privileges granted by the State, may not support candidates and political parties. 

Article L 58 : Every candidate shall refrain from any action or attitude, gesture or any other offensive behavior, dishonourable, illegal or immoral and must ensure the proper conduct of the election campaign. 

Article L 59: Any candidate or list of candidates has equitable access to the media of the State during the election campaign.

Article L 60: The Guinean Radio and Television Stations and the Rural Radio stations announce meetings involving electoral candidates.

Article L 61: During the election campaign, the time and schedule of broadcasts on Radio and Television, the conditions of their production and achievement, the manner of their programming and distribution are determined by decision of the Minister of Information, on the proposal of the National Council of Communication.

Article L 62: The Supreme Court shall ensure the regularity of the election campaign.
It shall ensure, through the National Council of Communication, that the principle of equal treatment between the candidates is respected in the state printing media and the news programmes of the Guinean Radio and Television Stations and the Rural Radio stations regarding reproduction and the comments of speeches, writings, the activities of candidates and political parties as well as the presentation of these candidates and the political parties. 
The National Council of Communication makes recommendations to the competent authorities and may apply to the Supreme Court in case of non-compliance with the provisions of this law in the field of communication.
The Supreme Court, if necessary, intervenes to ensure that equality is respected.

Article L 63: The Minister of Information, in addition to the emission time available to each candidate and each political party engaged in an election, hold under the supervision of the National Council of Communication, contradictory debates on radio and television.

Article L 64: Either motion or at the request of the National Council of Communication, the Supreme Court may suspend the broadcast of the official campaign, in the twenty four hours following the completion of this program, if the speaker's words is a serious breach of the obligations of political parties resulting from Article 1 of the Fundamental Law, particularly with regard to respect:
-Republican character, secular and democratic State;
-That all citizens are equal, irrespective of their origin, race, ethnicity, religion and opinion;
-Institutions of the Republic;
-National independence, territorial integrity and unity of the state;
-Of public order and freedoms.
The referral of the Supreme Court suspends the broadcast in question. Supreme Court sits within a period of forty-eight hours from the date of referral.
It may prohibit the broadcast, in whole or in part. If the National Council of Communication does refer to the Supreme Court within twenty-four hours or, if the Supreme Court does not sit within the time specified above, the issue shall be broadcast at the earliest.

Chapter 7: Operations to Vote

Section 1: Preparations Of Operations to Ballot

Article L 65: Voters are summoned by a decree published in National Gazette:
-Thirty-eight days before the election for the presidential elections;
-Seventy days before the election for the legislative elections;
-Sixty days before the election for the municipal elections and elections of Communities of Rural Development.
In case of cancellation, voters are called for new elections taking place sixty days after the cancellation.

Article L 66: The electoral districts are, as applicable:
-The quarter or district, for the election of councils of quarter and district;
- Community of Rural Development for the council of the community;
-The Commune, in the communal elections;
-Prefecture and Communes of Conakry, for the legislative elections in uninominal poll;
-The country for the legislative elections of list of candidates for proportional representation and for the presidential elections.
The electoral districts may only be amended by law.

 

Article L 67: In electoral districts, voters are divided by Act of the Minister of the Interior or the Prefect, in as many polling stations as required by the number of voters and local constraints.

Section 2: Voting

Article L 68: Election Day is set by Presidential decree. The ballot only lasts a single day throughout the national territory. It opens seven hours in the morning and ends in eighteen hours in the evening. It takes place on a Sunday.
However, in order to facilitate the exercise of voting rights, the competent authority may, in exceptional cases, take measures to the effect of delaying the closing time of voting in all or part of a constituency, charge for it to report to the higher authority. Mention is made of these acts in the minutes. These acts are immediately displayed at the entrance of polling stations.

Article L 69: In each room of balloting, the Administrative Commission deposits the ballots on the tables prepared for that purpose. The wording and technical characteristics of these ballots are defined by regulation. Communication is made to the Supreme Court by the Minister of the Interior.

Article L 70: The vote takes place in envelopes provided by the Administration. The envelopes are of a uniform type, opaque and not wet-glue. On polling day, they are made available to voters in the voting room. Before the ballot, the Board should note that the number of envelopes corresponds exactly to that of registered voters.
If  these envelopes run out, the Chairman of the polling station is required to obtain some from the Administrative Commission. Mention must be made in the minutes of the number of envelopes provided.

Article L 71: There shall be established a polling station for a thousand voters at most. The list of polling stations is the subject of a decision of the Minister of Interior, thirty days before the election. The order is transmitted through the administrative authorities, to the Mayors and Presidents of Communities of Rural Development that ensure the publication in the district under their jurisdiction.
The office is composed of:
-A President;
-Of a Vice-President;
-A Secretary;
-Two Assessors.

Article L 72: The members of the polling station shall be appointed by decision of the Minister of the Interior on the proposal of the prefects. They are required by the prefects among voters in the constituency, to the exclusion of candidates and their direct relatives or affinity to the fourth degree.
The decision of the Minister of Interior and the requisition of the Prefect are notified to those concerned by the prefect and the sub-prefect.
The head of the public security forces competent receives amplification.
In the event of failure of the office of President, it is officially replaced by the Vice-President.
In the event of failure of a member of the bureau noted at the opening or during polling, it is proceeded to his replacement by the President, who chose by lot from among the electors present who can read and write French. Mention is made in minutes.
The Minister of the Interior designates the Presidents of the polling station and shall ensure their allocation in such a way that no one is required to chair a polling station in the locality of where it comes from or resides.
In the same vein, it should be careful to make a good distribution of polling stations within a single electoral constituency.
The Presidents of polling station will be selected among managers of the State known for their honesty, integrity and good character.

Article L 73: The chairman of the polling station has police powers within the polling station and can expel any person who disrupts the operations of the vote. No armed force shall not; without his permission, be placed in the voting room or its immediate vicinity, or intervene in any way whatsoever. No one can enter the polling room, carrying a concealed apparent or weapon, with the exception of members of the public forces legally required.

Article L 74: The members of the polling station are responsible for all the operations assigned to them by the present law and regulations. Candidates can ask on their initiative to be represented in these operations.

Article L 75: Every voter on the list of electors in the constituency, is entitled to vote in the office to which he was attached, unless it is deprived of the right to vote after his inclusion.
However, subject to verification of their identity cards, their voter’s cards, are allowed to vote outside their constituency, members of polling stations, officials of the security forces, the military, journalists, the aircraft crews, sailors and all other people on the move for reasons of service, as well as the candidates on the list of a political party with regard to the parliamentary elections.
In each polling station, he shall be a registry of full name, affiliation and occupation of all electors who is supposed to vote, under the exemptions provided by this article.

Article L 76: In each polling station, there is a voting booth for two hundred and fifty registered voters at most. Voting booth should not be placed so as to hide it from the public the electoral process.

Article L 77: At no time during the balloting, the number of officers present in the polling station may not be less than three.

Article L 78: On entering the hall to vote, the voter must present their voter registration card.
The voter must also be seen at the same time with his identity card by the presentation of one of the items listed in Article 21. The voter affix the fingerprint of his left thumb in the place reserved for this purpose on the electoral roll for signature.
These requirements having been satisfied, the voter takes himself an envelope and a ballot paper for each candidate or list of candidates and proceeded alone in the voting booth where he places the ballot paper of his choice in the envelope. He then makes sure that he holds a single envelope. The President notes without touching the envelope that the voter introduces himself in the ballot box.

Article L 79: Every voter suffering infirmity, placing him in impossibility to put his ballot paper in the envelope and bring it in the ballot box is allowed to be assisted by an elector of his choice.

Article L 80: The ballot box should have only one opening in which to pass the envelope containing the ballot paper. Before the start of the ballot, it must have been closed with two different locks, and to the voters and delegates of candidates find that it is empty. The keys remain, one in the hands of the President of the polling station and the other in the hands of the oldest assessor. 

Article L 81: By the closure of polling, the electoral list of signature is signed by all members of the polling station.

Section 3: The Counting

Article L 82: Immediately after the closure of polling, there shall be counting in the following manner:
The ballot box is opened and the number of envelopes is checked.
If the number is greater or less than that of signatures, it is mentioned in the minutes.
The Office of vote chooses among voters present, a number of tellers, who can read and write French, to be officially selected to train with the polling, the commission of counting. They are divided in groups of four or more.
The counting of votes in each polling will take place before the delegates of political parties and candidates.

Article L 83: In each group, one of the tellers extract each ballot envelope and hand it unfolded to another teller, the latter shall read aloud; the indications on the ballot are identified by at least two tellers on lists prepared for that purpose.

Article L 84: The invalid ballots are not regarded as votes cast during vote counting.
Shall be deemed invalid ballots:
1) envelope without ballot paper or ballot paper without envelope;
2) several different ballot paper in a single envelope;
3) torn envelopes or ballot papers, or having written or indications that the voters have made themselves known;
4) ballot papers fully or partially crossed out;
5) ballot papers or envelopes non-regulatory.
The invalid ballot papers and envelopes are attached to the report and counter-signed by the officers. They should be clearly marked causes of their invalidity.
The number of invalid ballots was subtracted from the number of registered voters on the electoral roll, to determine the actual number of voters who voted.

Article L 85 : The votes obtained by candidate or list of candidates are aggregated and recorded by the secretary of the office. In each polling station, the results of the counting are the subject of a minute written in indelible ink. It includes, where appropriate, comments or reservations of the candidates or their representatives. The minutes of votes is completed in three copies signed by the members of the polling station. Immediately after the counting, and since the establishment of minutes, the result of the ballot is made public by the President of the polling station and displayed by him in the voting room, this figure is merely temporary .
At his own expense, any legal representative of a political party can have a copy of the minutes of the preliminary results.

Article L 86: Each President of the polling station, transmits by the fastest way to the Secretariat of the Electoral district one of the copies of the minutes accompanied by documents that must be attached, all meant to be given to the commission of Census Voting Planned for each type of election.

Article L 87: The second copy of the minutes of polling is sent under seal through the fastest and safest means in the Minister of the Interior.
In this example are attached:
-Envelopes and ballot papers cancelled by the Bureau;
-A sheet of counting of votes duly adopted;
-Claims submitted by the candidates or their representatives;
-Possibly the comments of the polling station about the election.
The third copy is kept at the sub-prefecture or Prefecture depending on the type of election.

Article L 88: The identification of votes will be a breakdown of the voting results submitted by the different polling stations in the constituency. The identification of votes will be conducted in the presence of Presidents of polling stations and representatives of candidates or lists of candidates by an administrative commission appointed by the central authority for each type of election and chaired in all cases by the 'judicial authority designated by the Supreme Court. The results concluded by each polling station and the documents annexed can under no circumstances be changed.

Article L 89: The minutes of the census, which is a summary document, is drawn up in duplicate in the presence of the candidates or their representatives. It is signed by all members of the Central Administrative Commission, which sends a copy to Minister of the Interior.
A copy of the record referred to in the above paragraph is displayed at the headquarters of the Central Commission of the Census.

Article L 90: The signature lists for each polling station, signed by the President and assessors are filed for eight days to the Secretariat of the electoral district where they are viewed without displacing it by any elector who wishes to.

Article L 91: Any candidate or his duly authorized representative shall have the right, within the limits of his constituency, can supervise all operations of voting, counting of ballot and counting of votes in all areas where these operations are carried out. It can be entered into the minutes, any comments or protests over the process.

Article L 92: The Minister of the Interior after completing the aggregation of results, makes public this aggregation.

Section 4: The Vote By Proxy

Article L 93: Can exercise, upon their request, their right to vote by proxy, voters belonging to one of the categories listed below chosen by Bonds out of the electoral district in which they were enrolled.
1) military and paramilitary and more generally the voters legally absent from their homes to polling day;
2) workers in regular transportation;
3) patients hospitalized or treated at home;
4) severely disabled and infirm.

Article L 94: The agent must exercise his right of election and be registered on the electoral roll of that of the grantor or have completed his right to vote in the constituency.

Article L 95: Proxies given by the persons referred to in Article L 93 above shall be authenticated by the competent authorities. For military and paramilitary, this formality is completed before the unit commander.

Article L 96: Each agent may only use a proxy at a constituency.

Article L 97: The agent participating in the elections under the conditions provided for in Article L 78 must present the voter's card of the principal. The proxy order is stamped with a wet seal.

Article L 98: The principal may revoke its proxy at any time before the vote. he may vote in person if present at the polling station before the agent has exercised its powers.

Article L 99: In the event of death or deprivation of civil rights and civic responsibilities of the principal, the order of proxy is set aside straightly.

Article L 100: The proxy is valid for a single ballot.

Part 2: Special Provisions Relating To The Election Of Council Of District And Quarter

Article L 101: An act of the Minister of Interior sets the procedure for the election of District and Quarter Councils and the number of advisors.

Part 3: Special Provisions Relating To The Election Of Community Councils   

Article L 102: The Community Councils are elected through proportional representation list for single-round by the inhabitants of the Community of Rural Development, for a term of four years. The period runs from the last renewal of each General Council irrespective of the date of this renewal.
The number of advisers by Community of Rural Development was established by a decision of the Minister of Interior.

Article L 103: If the community has lost, by the fact vacancies occurred, the third of its members, elections will be conducted within six months from the last vacancy.
At the same time, elections will be held in the event of dissolution of the Council and the resignation of all its members.  In the year preceding the renewal of the General Council, the elections are mandatory only if the Council has lost half of its members.

Article L 104: The nomination follows the filing in the sub-prefecture of a list that meets the requirements of sections provided in the articles L 105, L 106 and L 107. This statement is made collectively by one of the candidates on the list. The declaration signed by each candidate explicitly:
-The full name, any aliases, date and place of birth, occupation and address of each candidate;
-The name of the list;
-The name of the Community of Rural Development.
The statement contains, as an appendix, the program will be developed during the election campaign. A receipt of the statement is issued to declaring.

Article L105: The nomination must be filed in thirty days before polling day by the representative of the list.

Article L 106: The list of candidates for the Community Council shall include more many candidates than seats to be filled.

Article L 107: Following receipt of applications, no addition or deletion or modification of the order of presentation can take place except in cases of death or legal obstacle.
In this case the agent makes the list without delay an additional statement of candidacy for the approving authority, which receives and takes charge of the publication by displaying at all polling stations, and where appropriate, the dissemination by radio or any other means of communication. The declaration will specify the rank of replacement candidate on the list.

Article L 108: No person may be a candidate on more than one list, and in more than one constituency.

Article L 109: Any rejection of the application or a list of candidates must be motivated. This rejection must be notified within a period of ten days from the date of filing. The rejection can be appealed before the Tribunal of First Instance or the Justice of the Peace within two days from the date of notification of rejection. The Tribunal or the Justice of the Peace sits within five days and notify immediately the decision of the stakeholders and the Prefect that registers the candidate or candidates to the list of candidates, if such is the Tribunal's decision.
The Tribunal's decision is not subject to any appeal.

Article L 110: The operations of voting and the counting are carried out in accordance with the provisions of Title 1, Chapter 7 of this Act.
The Administrative Commission of the sub-Prefecture checks and centralizes the results recorded by the Electoral Commissions of Communities of Rural Development and publishes the aggregation of results, two days after the balloting. If no dispute regarding the regularity of elections has been filed within five days of publication of the aggregation of results, the Minister of the Interior announce the final results.

Article L 111: The litigation that may arise in connection with the elections is under consideration by the Administrative Commission of sub-prefecture.
Representatives of the lists of candidates concerned in or affected do not vote.

Article L 112: Any candidate or his representative has the right to challenge the legality of voting operations in accordance with the provisions of article L 91 by filing a claim in the polling station where he voted. That complaint is recorded in the minutes of the polling station and forwarded to the Administrative Commission of the Sub-Prefecture. The Commission shall decide on all claims submitted in accordance with the provisions of Article L101. It pronounces its decisions within a maximum period of five days from the date of referral. They decide without costs of the proceedings after a simple warning given to all parties concerned. Its decisions may be appealed before the Tribunal or the Justice of the Peace, which decides within five days of the referral. The judgement of the Tribunal of Justice and Peace, which is subject to no appeal is notified of the parties concerned and forwarded to the Ministry of Interior. If cancelled, new elections are held within sixty days after the cancellation.

Part 4: Special Provisions Relating To The Election Of Advisers Communaux

Article L 113: The Municipal Council is elected by proportional representation list for single round. The number of Councillors shall be as follows:
-11 Councillors  for the Council of Communal whose population is less than or equal to 10000;
-15 Councillors for 10001 to 30000 inhabitants;
-19 Councillor for 30001 to 40000 inhabitants;
-23 Councillors for 40001 to 50000 inhabitants;
-27 Councillors for 50001 to 60000 inhabitants;
-31 Councillors  for 60001 to 100000; For Towns with more than 100000 inhabitants, the number of consultants has increased by one unit for each additional 25000 residents within the maximum limit of 41 Councillors.

Article L114: The Municipal Councillors are elected for a term of four years. The period runs from the last renewal of each Council, it may have been the date of this renewal. However, a decree may shorten or extend the mandate of the municipal council in order to bring its renewal with the renewal date generally from local councils.

Article L 115: If the Municipal Council has lost, as a result of the vacancy thirds of its members, there shall be elections within a period of sixty days after the last vacancy. At the same time, elections are also taking place in the event of cancellation of elections, dissolution of the municipal Council or resignation of all its members. In the year preceding the renewal of general councils, the elections are mandatory only if the municipal Council has lost half of its members.

Article L 116:Voters are summoned in accordance with the provisions of article L 65. The casting of votes, counting and the announcement of the results is carried out in accordance with the provisions of chapter 7, part 1 of this Law. The provisions of Articles L 103 to L111 included are applicable to elections.

Part 5: Special Provisions Relating to The Election Of Members Of The National Assembly. 

Chapter 1: The Mode Of Election Of MPs

Article L117: In accordance with the provisions of Article 48, paragraph 1 of the Fundamental Law, no person may be a candidate for election to the National Assembly, if it is submitted by a legally constituted political party.

Article L 118: Each deputy is representative of the nation as a whole. Two third of the MPs are elected through a national list of proportional representation. The communes in Conakry and prefectures are constituencies for the election of one third of MPs in single-seat majority voting in a ballot.

Article L 119: To determine the number of MPs elected for each national list of candidates, it is proceeded in the following manner:
Dividing the total number of votes cast by the number of MPs to be elected; as many times this quotient is contained in the number of votes obtained by a list, provided it gets elected candidates. Once that process is complete, the remaining vacancies are attributed to the lists enjoying the highest remainders. In case of a tie, the seat is allocated to older candidates.

Article L 120: Each national list must include a number of candidates equal to the number of seats to be filled. The seats are allocated to candidates according to the order of presentation on each list.

Article L 121: MP elected in single mandate constituencies whose seat becomes vacant as a result of death, resignation, acceptance of a governmental function, or any other cause, shall be replaced as a result of election. The elections in the constituency concerned take place within six months after the declaration of vacant.
If the latter occurs in the last year of the legislature, there is no filling of vacancy.
The MP elected on national lists whose seat becomes vacant as a result of death, resignation, acceptance of a governmental function, or any other cause that invalidation replaced by the unelected first candidate on the list of the holder in the order of this list at the time of the election.
The President of the National Assembly calls for the replacement exercise the mandate of the incumbent. This replacement, whatever its cause, is irrevocable.

 

Article L 122: In the event that an act of the Minister of the Interior issued under sections L 143, L 145, L 146 and L 147, agents of lists of candidates may, within twenty-four hours of notification of decision or its publication, appeal to the Supreme Court, which decides within three days after the date of registration of the complaint.

Article L 123: After the deadline for national lists, no substitutions, no withdrawal of candidacy, no permutation in the order of candidates on a list is allowed.
However, between that date and the day before the vote at zero hour, in the event of death or disqualification of one or more candidates, the agent of the list makes without delay an additional statement of candidacy for the ministry in charge of the Interior which receives, provides the publication by displaying at all polling stations concerned and if necessary, broadcast by radio or other means of communication.
The declaration will specify the rank of the candidate of replacement on the list.

Article L 124: The mandate of the MPs to the National Assembly expires at the opening of the first regular session after the fifth year of their election.
New Assembly, whose election of MPs is organized in the quarter of the year preceding the session, takes office on that date.

Article L 125: In the event of dissolution, in accordance with the provisions of Article 76 of the Fundamental Law, the general elections are held within sixty days of the dissolution.

Chapter 2: Conditions Of Eligibility

Article L 126: Any citizen who qualifies elector can be elected to the National Assembly if he is presented by a legally constituted political party and under the conditions and subject to the laws and regulations in force.

Article L 127: Nobody shall be elected to the National Assembly if he is younger than twenty-five years of age on the day of filing of his candidacy.

Article L 128: The naturalized aliens are eligible at the end of a period of ten years from the date of the decree of naturalization, provided they reside in Guinea since then.

Chapter 3: The System Of Ineligibility

Article L 129: May not be elected as MPs:
-Those suffering from insanity or are placed under safeguards of justice (as defined in the Civil Code)
-Those who are rescued by municipal budgets, the budgets of prefecture, the State budget and welfare;
-Those who have been convicted for a criminal offence, except upon presentation of an Act of rehabilitation.

Article L 130: Are ineligible, the military and paramilitary forces of all ranks and the Judges/Magistrates in a position of service.
Also ineligible in the Prefectures and municipalities in which they hold or have held for at least one year:
-Prefects;
-The Secretaries General of Prefectures and Municipalities;
-Sub-prefects and their deputies.
The treasurers, and the recipients and payers at all levels may not be candidates for the duration of their office.

Article L131: Is deposed by right of his office, MP whose ineligibility is revealed after the declaration of results of the ballot or who, during his term of office, is located in one of the cases of disqualification provided in this Act.
Deprivation is proven by the Supreme Court at the request of the Bureau of the Assembly.

Chapter 4: Incompatibilities

Article L 132: The function of MP is incompatible with membership of the Economic and Social Council.

Article L 133: The exercise of any non-elective public service is incompatible with the function of MP.
Accordingly, any person, who carries one of the functions referred to in the preceding paragraph, elected to the National Assembly is replaced in his post and placed in the position intended for this purpose by the governing status within eight days after he took office, or in the event of contesting the election, in the eight days after the decision of validation.
The exercise of the functions entrusted by a foreign state or an international organization and paid on their fund is also incompatible with the functions of MP.
However, members of the teaching staff in higher education are not affected by the provisions of the first two paragraphs of this article.

Article L 134: Members may, during their tenure, be appointed by the Head of State of temporary administrative missions, with the concurrence of the Bureau of the Assembly..
The cumulating of the PM status and that of the mission shall not exceed six months.
At the expiration of that period, the mission ceases to be temporary and is governed by the provisions of Article L 133 unless it is renewed by Act of the Council of Ministers for a further period of six months, but the total duration of the mission may not exceed twenty-four months. In any event, the exercise of the functions of MP is suspended for the duration of the mission, which resumed at the end of it.

Article L 135: Are incompatible with the functions of MP, the position of Chairman and CEO as well as Managing Director and Deputy Managing General exercised in public enterprises and enterprises under state control.

 

It is equally so for all functions exercised permanently as an advisor to the same institutions or enterprises, as well as shareholders in the enterprises under state control. Companies, businesses and institutions described above comply with the definitions in the laws in force in the Republic of Guinea.

Article L 136: Are incompatible with the functions of MP, the position of head of the company, Chairman and Chief Executive Officer, Managing Director, General Director, Deputy General Director or CEO, exercised in: 
1) Companies, firms or institutions, benefiting in the form of guaranteed of interest or subsidy, or equivalent, benefits provided by the State or by a public body, except where these benefits accrue to the automatic application of a general law or regulation generally;
2) Companies object of which is purely financial and forming public and private companies and credit;
3) Companies and enterprises activities of which is mainly the execution of works, the provision of supplies or services for the account or under the control of the State, a community or an institution of which more than half of the share capital is made up of companies or enterprises having such activities.

Article L 137: It prohibits any MP from exercising during his term of office a function of CEO, Manager or any function permanently occupied in enterprises, institutions or companies mentioned in the preceding article.
It also prohibits any MP to be, during his term of office, a majority shareholder of such a company, institution or corporation.
It also prohibits any MP from exercising during their term of office the position of Company manager, Chief Executive Officer, Managing Director, Director General, Deputy Director General and CEO, or any function performed permanently as counsel in a company, institution, enterprise whatever.
It also forbids any MP to be, during his term of office, a majority shareholder of such a corporation, institution or corporation.
However, the prohibitions listed in four paragraphs above do not apply when the functions were performed at the time of the first election of the person concerned as a Member of Parliament, or when the situation of majority shareholder existed during the first election. In this case, the current year mandate of any new function referred to the four preceding paragraphs shall be subject to prior authorization from the Office of the National Assembly.

Article L 138: Notwithstanding the provisions of the preceding articles, Members of Parliament, members of another Assembly (Community of Rural Development, for example) or a city council may be appointed by that Assembly or this council to represent them in the bodies of regional or Local interest provided that these agencies do not have as object to make or distribute profits and that the persons concerned do not occupy any remunerated position..
In addition, the MPs, even non-members of the Assembly or council described above, may perform functions:
-Chairman of the Board;
-Managing Director, or a member of the board of directors of companies with public participation majority or corporations with an exclusively social object when these functions are not remunerated.
