Article L 139: It is prohibited for any Trial Lawyer, when he is invested with the mandate of a MP to perform directly or indirectly through an association, business associate, a collaborator or a Secretary except to the High Court of Justice, every act of his profession in business against which criminal charges are brought before the criminal courts for crimes or offences against public affairs in the press or interference with credit and saving.
It is prohibited under the same conditions to plead or check against the government, decentralized local government or public institutions and companies under state control.

Article L 140: It is prohibited for any MP to include or let his name, followed by an indication of his capacity as MP, be included in any publicity relating to any financial, industrial or commercial company. 
Are punishable by imprisonment of one to six months and a fine of 100,000 to 500,000 FG, founders, directors or managers of companies or establishments having commercial, industrial or financial interest which have included or left included the name of an MP in the interest of the company they run or they intend to found. In case of repetition, the penalties provided above may be doubled.

Article L 141: The MP who, during his election lies in a case of inconsistency referred to in this chapter is required to establish within eight days after he took office that he has resigned from functions incompatible with his mandate as MP or he is no longer in the position of majority shareholder declared incompatible under Articles L 135 paragraph 1, and L 137, paragraph 4, or if he holds a public office, that he has asked to be placed in the  position provided by his special status. Failing that, he is dismissed from office, unless he voluntarily resigns his tenure as MP.
The MP who, during his term of office, has accepted an office incompatible with it, or who has been in the position of majority shareholder declared incompatible under Articles L 135 paragraph 1 and L 137, paragraph 4, or who disregarded the need for prior authorization from the Bureau of the National Assembly provided for in Article L 137 last paragraph, is also dismissed from office, unless he voluntarily resigns his tenure as MP.
The resignation is observed in all cases by the Supreme Court at the request of the Bureau of the National Assembly. It does not carry ineligibility.

Chapter 5: The Declaration Of Application

Article L 142: In accordance with the provisions of Article 48 paragraph one of the Fundamental Law, any legally constituted political party and willing to participate in the legislative elections should, as appropriate, make one or two statements:
-The first concerns the nominations for the post voting;
-The second concerns the lists of candidates nationwide proportional representation.
Statements must include:
1) Name of Political Party, which presents the candidate;
2) Color and the logo or sign or symbol chosen for the printing of ballot papers;
3) Full name, affiliation, the date and place of birth with precision of the service, employment and the duty, if it is a Government employee;
4) Signature of each candidate;
5) Indication of the constituency in which the candidate is, with regard to the uninominal majority poll;
6) In the annex, the program will be developed during the election campaign.
For the uninominal majority poll:
-The parties are not required to nominate a candidate in each electoral district;
-The same person cannot be a candidate in more than one constituency.
For the proportional:
-The list should conform to the provisions of Article L 144.
The same person may not be a candidate on more than one list of candidates and can not be a candidate for both the majority and proportional polls.

Article L 143: The declarations of candidacy must be accompanied for each candidate, with the following documents:
1) A birth certificate;
2) A bulletin No. 3 from criminal records delivered at least three months ago;
3) A statement that certifies that the candidate is on a single list or in a single constituency and that they are not in any of the cases provided for ineligibility  Act;
4) Deposit bail slip  under Article L 181.
The statements are also accompanied by a certificate by which the Political Party invests interested as the candidates.

Article L 144: The declarations of candidacy are filed with the Ministry of the Interior, fifty days before the date of the vote by the representative of the Political Party which gave his candidacy. The Ministry of the Interior issued a receipt of these deposits. The receipt does not prejudge the validity of nominations.

Article L 145: Is not admissible the statement that:
1) did not include the required number of candidates;
2) did not include the indications provided for in Article L 142;
3) is not accompanied by documents provided for in Article L 143.
In cases where, for one of the reasons listed above, the Ministry of the Interior believes that a list is not admissible, he shall notify the reasons for its decision to the representative of the list within three days of its filing.

Article L 146: If it appears that a declaration of candidacy was filed on behalf of a person ineligible or in any other event of a discrepancy, the Ministry of the Interior rejects the declaration within seven days after the submission of the application and notify the rejection to the candidate or his representative.
The candidate or his representative has three days to challenge the decision before the Supreme Court, which decides within seven days of receiving it.
If the deadline mentioned in the first paragraph, is not fulfilled, the application must be received.

Article L 147: Not later than thirty days before the election, the Minister of the Interior publishes by Act the list of candidates. This order is issued after submission to the Minister of the Interior by the agent of the candidate or list, of the receipt or payment bond provided by Articles L 181 L 182 and L 183 of this Act.
In case of challenge of the lists published, the challenge is filed to the Supreme Court by the concerned parties within forty eight hours of their publication. Supreme Court sits within forty-eight hours of the referral and authorizes the Minister of the Interior to publish the final list.

Chapter 6: The Electoral Campaign

Article L 148: The campaign for the election of MPs to the National Assembly, shall be conducted in accordance with the provisions of chapter 6 Title 1 of this Act.

Chapter 7: Elections And Operations Of Voting Recencement

Article L 149: Voters are summoned by a Presidential decree issued thirty days before the elections in accordance with Article L 65.

Article L 150: The provisions of Articles L 83, L 85, L 86 and L 88 are applicable to the election of MPs to the National Assembly.

Article L 151: Considering all the minutes of the Central Administrative Commission, the Minister of the Interior makes the general census of votes.
If during the census, it appears that the inconsistency of the results contained in the records makes them unusable or if minutes were marred by a substantive defect affecting the sincerity of their writing, the Minister responsible for Interior, after verification of the minutes of the polling stations, declared by decision, the invalidity of those minutes.
In this case, the number of registered voter appearing on the minutes declared invalid is not reflected in the general vote.
At the end of this census, the Minister of the Interior prepares minutes immediately forward it to the Supreme Court.

Article 152: The Minister of the Interior shall make public the aggregation of results within the maximum period of 48 hours.

Article L 153: If no dispute regarding the regularity of elections has been filed at the Registry of the Supreme Court by one of the candidates within the period provided for in Article L 154, the Supreme Court declares MPs finally elected on the eighth day following the publication of the comprehensive aggregation of results.

Chapter 8: For Contentious

Article L 154: Candidates have a period of five days from the publication of the aggregation of results to contest of the regularity of electoral operations. The complaints are filed with the Registrar of the Supreme Court. A receipt is given by the Registrar-in-chief. Under penalty of inadmissibility the appeal must specify the facts and the alleged means alleged and meet deadlines for filing.

Article L 155: The complaints are sent by the Chief Registrar of the Supreme Court to agents of the candidates or lists who have a maximum period of three days to file their reply.
A receipt is given of filing of the brief by the Registrar-in-chief.

Article L 156: The Supreme Court examines and sets all claims definitively and rules on the legality of the election of members of the National Assembly. In cases where it finds the existence of irregularities, it can assess whether, in view of the nature and gravity of these irregularities, it is necessary to maintain the results of the comprehensive aggregation made public by the Minister of the Interior in accordance with the provisions of Article L 152, either makes their complete or partial cancellation.
Supreme Court sits on request within ten days of the filing. Its final decision stands for proclamation or cancellation of the election.
If cancelled, it is to hold a new election within thirty days.

Part 6: Special Provisions Relating To The Election Of The President Of The Republic

Chapter 1: The Filing Of Nominations

Article L 157: Every candidate for the Presidency of the Republic must be:
-Guinean of nationality by birth;
-Enjoy their civil and political rights;
-Be forty years old and at least seventy years at the date of filing the application.

Article L 158: Deposits of candidacies are made to the Registry of the Supreme Court forty days and at least sixty before polling day.

Article L 159: The declaration of candidacy for the Presidency of the Republic by the party shall contain:
1) the full name, date and place of birth and affiliation of the candidate;
2) a statement that the applicant is of Guinean nationality of birth and that he enjoys his civil and political rights in accordance with article L 157 of this Act;
3) the name of the political party that presents the candidate;
4) the signature of the applicant;
5) the color chosen for the printing of ballot papers and possibly a symbol or sign which should be included.

Article L 160: The nomination must be accompanied by:
-A certificate of nationality;
-A birth certificate;
-A bulletin No. 3 of the police Criminal record dating for less than three months;
-A medical certificate of inspection and check-up dating for less than three months;
-The deposit bail slip under Article L 181.

Article L 161: To ensure the validity of applications filed and the consent of the candidates, the Supreme Court can carry out any investigation, which it deems appropriate.

Article L 162: In accordance with Article 26, paragraph 3 of the Fundamental Law, the Supreme Court shall establish and publish the list of candidates thirty-nine days before the first round of balloting. This publication is issued by display at the Registry of the Supreme Court. Voters are summoned by decree thirty-eight days before the election.

Article L 163: The right to claim against any candidature is open to any legally constituted political party. Claims must be received by the Registry of the Supreme Court before the expiry of the day following the posting of the list of candidates.
Supreme Court rules without delay.

Article L 164: If the Supreme Court finds for death or permanent inability of any candidate for the Presidency of the Republic on the list provided for in Article L 162, it decides, if necessary, to reopen the periods during which new nominations can be filed. In this case, a new election date is set in the conditions provided for in paragraph 3 of Article 25 of the Fundamental Law.

Article L 165: In the case where, after the first ballot, no candidate obtains an absolute majority, there shall be a second ballot within the time limits and conditions laid down in Article 25, paragraph 2 and Article 29 paragraph 2 of the Fundamental Law.
Withdrawals of any application for the second round are brought to the attention of the Supreme Court by the candidates not later than 24 hours after the proclamation of the result of the first round.
The Supreme Court then adopts and publishes by display the list of only two candidates to go to the second round.

Article L 166: The convening of voters for the second round is made by decree seven days before the election.

Chapter 2: The Electoral Campaign

Article L 167: The electoral campaign opens thirty days before the polling day and closes it at zero hour. In the event of a second round, the election campaign opened on the day after the announcement of the results of the first round and closed on the eve of the second round at zero hour.
It takes place in both cases in accordance with the provisions of chapter 6, part 1 of this Act.

Chapter 3: Elections Of Operations

Article L 168: The ballot for the election of the President shall be held in accordance with article 25 paragraph 1 of the Fundamental Law, forty five days and not more than thirty days before the date of expiry of the tenure of the President in office.
However, in the event of a vacancy provided for in Article 34 of the Fundamental Law, the ballot for the election of the President of the Republic is recognized by the Supreme Court, thirty-five days at least and fifty days at most after the opening of the vacancy.

Article L 169: The electorate is summoned by decree of the President of the Republic thirty-eight days before the election, in accordance with the provisions of article L 65 of this Act.
The counting of the votes, the census of votes, the publication of the results of polling, the aggregation of results and publication of this aggregation in accordance with the provisions of Title 1, Chapter 7, Section 3 of this Act.


Chapter 4: General Census Of Voting And The Announcement Of Results

Article L 170: The final counting of votes and transmission of Minutes of the census to the Supreme Court by the Minister of the Interior is carried out in accordance with the provisions of Article L 151.

Article L 171: The Minister of the Interior shall make public the aggregation of results within the maximum period of forty-eight hours.

Article L 172: If no dispute regarding the regularity of elections has been filed by one of the candidates to the Registry of the Supreme Court within eight days from the day when the first aggregation was published, the Supreme Court proclaims elected President of the Republic.
The candidate who obtains an absolute majority of votes for the first round, and a simple majority for the second round.
In case of dispute, the results are set forth in the conditions defined in Article L 176 of this Act.

Chapter 5: The Challenge

Article L 173: Under the conditions and time limits set by article 30 paragraph 1 of the Fundamental Law, a candidate in the election may contest the legality of the electoral operations in the form of a petition addressed to the First President of the Supreme Court.

Article L 174: The complaint is filed to the Registry of the Supreme Court.
It is acknowledged by the Registrar-in-chief.
To be accepted, the request must specify the facts and the alleged means and meet the deadlines for filing.

Article L 175: The complaint is forwarded by the Chief Registrar of the Supreme Court to other interested candidates who have a maximum period of 24 hours to lodge a response. It is given a receipt of filing of the brief by the Registrar-in-chief.

Article L 176: the Supreme Court rules within three days after the date of referral. Its final decision stands for proclamation or cancellation of the election.
If cancelled, new elections are held within sixty days.

Part 7: Financial Provisions

Article L 177: Acts of procedures, decisions and records relating to elections are exempt from stamp, registration and legal costs.
The voter cards, ballot papers, the circulars are exempt from stamps during election time.

Article L 178: Shall be borne by the state, the expenses resulting from the provision of voter cards, as well as the organization of elections. Expenses incurred by political parties during the election campaign are dependent on them.

Article L 179: The rates of pay for benefits inherent to the material preparation and conduct of elections to be borne by the government are determined by a joint decree of the Minister of Interior and that of Finance.

Article L 180: Election campaigns are financed by the means of:
-Resources of political parties;
-Eventual grants from the State granted fairly;
-Possibly, the income of applicants.
The modalities for implementing the provisions of this Article shall be determined by regulations.

Article L 181: At the suggestion of a Commission of Finance composed:
-The Minister of the Interior, President;
-The representative of the Minister of Finance, Raporteur;
-Representatives from each of the legally constituted parties, and engaged in the election, members;
-Minister of the Interior set by Official Act no later than sixty days before the election:
-The guarantee to be paid to the public treasury against a receipt, forty (40) days and fifty-nine days prior to the election, by the candidates or agents of the political parties taking part in a legislative election or Presidential;
-And the authorized ceiling on total expenditure can be incurred by a candidate or a political party taking part in a parliamentary or presidential election.

Article L 182: The guarantee represents the counterpart of the cost of printing of ballot papers, professions of faith and propaganda posters by the State under conditions established by the regulatory part of this electoral code.

Article L 183: The deposit shall be refunded to the candidates or representatives of political parties within fifteen days after the proclamation of the final results.
Those entitled to full reimbursement of bail are:
-Any candidate or elected with at least 5% of the votes cast in the election at uninominal majority in a single round of legislative;
-Any list having obtained a seat or at least 5% of the votes cast in the election of national lists by proportional representation;
-Any presidential candidate who receives at least 5% of the votes cast.

Article L 184: It is prohibited for any political party or any candidate taking part in a parliamentary or presidential election to engage in the electoral campaign expenditures in excess of the limits prescribed by the commission stated in Article L 181.

Article L 185: Any political party or candidate involved in an election must constitute for his election expenses, a fund called " electoral Fund " fed in accordance with the provisions of

Article L 180.

Article L 186: Political parties, candidates taking part in presidential or parliamentary elections are required to prepare a campaign account. The campaign account receives the "Trust election."
The campaign account is traces the origin of the "electoral Fund" and all the expenditure incurred during the electoral process.
The person in charge of election expenses must not draw but in this "election fund" to cover the election expenses.

Article L 187: Within thirty days following the proclamation of the final results, the political parties electoral or candidate electoral taken part in the ballot deposits with the Chamber of Accounts of the Supreme Court their campaign accounts accompanied by supporting documents of resources and expenditure made.
These accounts are certified to the Chamber of Accounts of the Supreme Court of Approved Accountants.
The Chamber of Accounts of the Supreme Court makes public the accounts of campaign in order to receive, within a period of fifteen days, the comments from citizens and political parties to the above accounts.

Article L 188: After verification of the supporting documents for the accounts, the Supreme Court makes its ruling. If there are substantial exceeded campaign expenditure compared to the authorized ceiling, the Chamber of Accounts of the Supreme Court addresses within fifteen days after the filing of accounts, a report to the prosecutor who must engage in legal proceedings against offenders.

Part 8: On Penalties

Article L 189: Anyone registered under a false name or a false quality, or who, by being concealed include an inability provided by law, or who seeks and obtains a listing on more than one list, will be punishable by an imprisonment of one to six months and a fine of 100,000 to 250,000 FG or one of those two penalties.

Article L 190: Any person who, through fraudulent misrepresentation or false certificates will be registered or attempted to be registered on the electoral roll, or who, through fraudulent means will be registered or will improperly remove a citizen, will be punished to the penalties prescribed in section L 189 of this Act.

Article L 191: Any person who, deprived of the right to vote, as a result of a court sentence, or as a result of bankruptcy not followed by rehabilitation, voted either by virtue of a registration prior to his disqualification, or by under a subsequent listing, but made without his participation, will be punished by the penalties provided for in Article L 189 of this Act.

Article L 192: Anyone who voted, either by virtue of a registration obtained fraudulently or under the false names and qualifications of a registered voter, shall be punished with imprisonment from six months to one year and a fine from 250 FG 500000 to 000 or one of those two penalties.

Article L 193: Shall be liable to the penalties prescribed in section L 192 people who took advantage of a multiple registration to vote more than once. The same penalty applies to anyone who has been prevented by voluntary breach of the law, listing for election of a citizen meeting the requirements under the present Code.

Article L 194: Any breach of the provisions of articles L 48, paragraph 3 , L 54  and L 55 will be punished with imprisonment from six months to one year and a fine from 100000 to 200000 FG or one of these penalties .

Article L 195: Whoever is in charge of receiving a ballot, counting of ballots containing the votes of citizens, removed, added or altered ballot papers, or voluntarily read a name other than the one registered, shall be punished with imprisonment of between six months and one year, a fine from 250000 to 500000 FG and the prohibition of the right to vote and be eligible for at least from five years to ten years.
All other persons guilty of the same facts stated in the first paragraph shall be punished by imprisonment for not less than six months and not more than one year, a fine of 100,000 to 250,000 FG or one of these penalties only.

Article L 196: With the exception of members of the security forces required by law, anyone who has entered a polling station with an apparent weapon will be liable to a fine from  250,000 to 500,000 FG. The punishment will be imprisonment for a term of fifteen days to three months and a fine from 50,000 to 100,000 FG where the weapon was concealed.

Article L 197: Will be punished by imprisonment for not less than fifteen days and a fine of 25,000 F, anyone who has introduced or attempted to introduce into polling station alcoholic beverages.
Anyone who introduced or attempted to introduce drugs into a polling station will be prosecuted and punished according to law.

Article L 198: Anyone with false news about slanderous or other fraudulent votes will have diverted one or more voters from voting, shall be punished with imprisonment from one month to one year and a fine 100,000 to 500,000 FG or one of those two penalties.

Article L 199: Anyone troubles operations of a polling station, affects the exercise of electoral law or the freedom to vote, or prohibits a candidate or his representative to attend the casting of votes, shall be punished by imprisonment from six months to two years and a fine from 250,000 to 100,0000 FG or one of those two penalties.
If the offender is carrying a weapon, he faces a prison sentence from one to five years and a fine from 500,000 to 1,500,000, or one of those two penalties.
When the offences specified in paragraphs 1 and 2 above are committed as a result of a concerted plan to be executed, the offender shall be punished with imprisonment from five to ten years, and the prohibition of the right to vote and be eligible for at least five years and not more than ten years and a fine of 250,000 to 1,500,000 FG.

Article L 200: Anyone who commits an offence or exercises violence against one or more members of a polling station, or, for assault or threats, will have delayed or prevented the electoral operations, shall be punished with imprisonment of six months to two years and a fine of 100,000 to 500,000 FG notwithstanding legal action can be initiated by the victim.

Article L 201: The abduction of irregular ballot boxes containing the votes cast and not yet counted, or the minutes or any record of the election results, shall be punished with imprisonment of one to five years and a fine of 250,000 FG to 1,500,000, or one of those two penalties.
If the abduction was carried out by a group of people and with violence, the penalty is five to ten years of imprisonment and a fine ranging from 1,500,000 to 3,000,000 FG.

Article L 202: The violation of the ballot box either by a member of the Bureau or through an agent of the authority responsible for the custody of the ballots not yet counted, will be punished by imprisonment of one to five years and a fine of 1,500,000 FG to 3,000,000 FG.

Article L 203: Anyone with donations or gifts in cash or in kind, with promises of gifts, favors, public or private employment or other benefits, will have influenced attempted to influence the vote of one or more electors or an electoral college to abstain from voting, shall be punished with imprisonment of three months to two years and a fine of 50,000FG to 500,000 FG or one of those two penalties.
These sentences are subject to civil forfeiture for a period of five years. Will be subject to the same penalties, those who have authorized or requested the same gifts, gifts or promises.

Article L 204: Any candidate, who, male fide, has endorsed a false statement about his eligibility or his presence on a list, shall be punished with imprisonment of one month to one year and a fine of 50,000 to 250,000 FG.

Article L 205: Whoever either in a commission to control voter, or in an administrative commission or in a polling station, or outside them, before, during or after an election, will have, by voluntary breach of the laws and regulations in force or by any manoeuvring or fraudulent acts, harmed or attempted to undermine the sincerity of the vote, prevented or attempted to prevent the electoral operations, violated or attempted to violate the secrecy of the vote or will have changed or attempted to change the result, shall be punished with imprisonment of one month to one year and a fine of 150,000FG to 600,000 FG.
The offender may also be deprived of his civic rights for at least two to five years. If he is an administrative or judicial officer or servant of the public authority, the penalty shall be doubled.

Article L 206: Those who by threat against a voter, or by making fear of losing their jobs or expose them to harm his person, family or property, have committed to vote or will have influenced or attempted to influence his vote will be punished with imprisonment of three months to one year and a fine of 50,000 to 500,000 FG, or one of those two penalties.
When these threats are accompanied by violence or assault, the sentences are those provided by article L 200 of this Act and the Penal Code.

Article L 207: Any person who violates the provisions referred to in article L 42 will be punished by imprisonment of one month to one year and the prohibition of the right to vote and be eligible for at least one year to five years.

Article L 208: Anyone who, in violation of articles L 56 and L 57, will have used or allowed use for his own interest, the attributes, property and means of the state, a government agency, association, a non-governmental organization, will be punished custodial sentences of six months to two years and a fine of 250,000 to 2,500,000 FG.

Article L 209: Any printer that violates the provisions of Article L 53 paragraph 4, shall be punished by a fine of 75,000 FG for every model of posters or ballot papers.
The offending posters or bulletins are immediately withdrawn from circulation by Act of the Minister of the Interior or the Prefect.

Article L 210: Any person who violates the provisions relating to the compilation of campaign under Article L 186 shall be punished with imprisonment of one to five years and a fine of 1,500,000 FG to 3,000,000FG, or one of the two penalties.

Article L 211: No action against a candidate, under sections L 202 and L 210 can be exercised before the proclamation of the poll.

Article L 212: The penalties provided for in this title shall apply without prejudice to any other penalties provided by the laws and regulations. Accomplices of the offences in this title are punishable.

Article L 213: Any sentence imposed in the framework of this Act shall not, under any circumstances, lead to the cancellation of an election regularly validated by the competent authorities.

Part 9: Final Provisions

 
Article L 214: This organic law, which repeals all contrary provisions will be published in the Official Gazette of the Republic of Guinea and enforced as law of the State.
Conakry, December 23, 1991
General Lansana Conté

It is in white color; and the General Annex, which gives a comparison of the budget for each Ministry, chapter-by-chapter, article-by-article with that of the previous year. It is in yellow color.
